Aphididae.description: Aphids are small, sap-sucking insects commonly found on plants. They are known for their rapid reproduction and their ability to transmit plant viruses.

Culicidae.description: Mosquitoes are flying insects, some of which are known for transmitting diseases like malaria, dengue, and Zika virus. They are blood-feeding parasites.

Formicidae.description: Ants are social insects that live in colonies. They are highly organized and often form large colonies with complex social structures.

Apidae.description: Bees are flying insects that are important pollinators. They include honey bees and bumble bees, which are critical for pollination in many ecosystems.

Vespidae.description: Wasps, including yellowjackets and hornets, are predatory insects known for their painful stings and aggressive behavior when threatened.

Dermestidae.description: Carpet beetles are small beetles known for their larvae, which feed on organic materials like wool, fur, and feathers, often causing damage to household items.

Curculionidae.description: Weevils are beetles with elongated snouts. They are known for their destructive feeding habits, especially in stored grains and plants.

Noctuidae.description: Owlet moths, including cutworms and earworms, are known for their nocturnal behavior. The larvae of some species can be agricultural pests.

Chrysomelidae.description: Leaf beetles are herbivorous beetles that feed on plants, sometimes causing significant damage to crops and ornamental plants.

Scarabaeidae.description: Scarab beetles include species like grubs and June beetles. They are often involved in the decomposition of organic material.

Lygaeidae.description: Seed bugs are a family of bugs that feed primarily on seeds. They can be pests of various crops.

Tortricidae.description: Tortricid moths are known for their larvae, which often roll or fold leaves for shelter. Some species, like the codling moth, are serious agricultural pests.

Carabidae.description: Ground beetles are predatory beetles that help control pest populations by preying on insects and other small animals in the soil.

Coccinellidae.description: Lady beetles, or ladybugs, are beneficial insects that feed on aphids and other plant pests, making them valuable for pest control.

Buprestidae.description: Jewel beetles are known for their shiny, metallic appearance. Some species are wood-borers and can cause damage to trees.

Reduviidae.description: Assassin bugs are predatory insects known for their aggressive hunting behavior. Some species are important in controlling pest populations.

Sesiidae.description: Clearwing moths have transparent wings and their larvae are often borers in plants, especially fruit trees and woody plants.

Pyralidae.description: Pyralid moths, including pantry and meal moths, are common household pests that infest dry food products like grains and cereals.

Thysanoptera.description: Thrips are tiny, slender insects that feed on plants, often causing damage by puncturing plant cells to suck out their contents.

Gelechiidae.description: Gelechiid moths are known for their larvae, which mine leaves or bore into twigs and stems, often damaging plants.

Miridae.description: Plant bugs are small, sap-sucking insects that can damage crops and ornamental plants by feeding on their juices.

Pentatomidae.description: Stink bugs are known for their ability to release a foul-smelling liquid when threatened. They are often agricultural pests.

Blattidae.description: Cockroaches are nocturnal insects that are often associated with poor sanitation. They are known for their resilience and ability to thrive in various environments.

Tipulidae.description: Crane flies resemble large mosquitoes and are typically harmless to humans. Their larvae, however, can be pests in lawns and gardens.

Elateridae.description: Click beetles are known for their ability to flip into the air when threatened. Some species' larvae, known as wireworms, are pests of crops.

Tingidae.description: Lace bugs are small insects with distinctive lace-like wings. They often damage plants by sucking sap from the leaves.

Psychodidae.description: Drain flies, also known as moth flies, are typically found near decaying organic matter like in drains or sewage systems.

Calliphoridae.description: Blow flies are often attracted to decaying animal flesh. Their larvae are used in forensic entomology to estimate time of death.

Tachinidae.description: Tachinid flies are parasitoid flies that lay eggs on or in the bodies of other insects, often killing their hosts.

Ixodidae.description: Ticks are parasitic arachnids that feed on the blood of mammals, birds, and sometimes reptiles. They are vectors for various diseases like Lyme disease.
